## 1. React JS React JS is an open-source JavaScript library used to build user interfaces. It was developed by Facebook. ### 1.1 Why React JS? - Performant websites - Fewer lines of code - Improves readability of code - Less time consuming - Open Source - Reusable code ### 1.2 Advantages of React JS - Easy to Learn - Large Community - Developer Toolset
## 2. Running JavaScript in HTML We can run JavaScript in HTML using the HTML `script` element. It is used to include JavaScript in HTML. ```html
``` Here the `type` attribute specifies the type of the script. To include an external JavaScript file, we can use the HTML `script` element with the attribute `src`. The `src` attribute specifies the path of an external JS file. ```html ``` When the browser comes across a `script` element while loading the HTML, it must wait for the script to download, execute it, and only then it can process the rest of the page. So, we need to put a `script` element at the bottom of the page. Then the browser can see elements above it and doesn’t block the page content from showing. If more than one `script` elements are in the HTML, the `script` elements will be executed in the order they appear.
## 3. Creating Elements using React JS ### 3.1 React CDN ```html ``` ### 3.2 React.createElement() The `React.createElement()` method is used to create an element using React JS. It is similar to the `document.createElement()` method in regular JavaScript. **Syntax**: ```terminal React.createElement(type, props); ``` **type** - Tag names like `div`, `h1` and `p`, etc. **props** - Properties like `className`, `onClick` and `id`, etc. Props are shorthand for properties. It is an optional argument. ```html ``` The `type` attribute value of the HTML `script` element should be `module` to run React JS. ### 3.3 Displaying Element The `ReactDOMClient.createRoot()` lets us to create a root element to display React Elements inside a browser DOM **Syntax**: ```terminal ReactDOMClient.createRoot(container); ``` The `root.render()` displays a React node into the React root’s browser DOM node **Syntax**: ```terminal root.render(reactElement); ``` **reactElement** - What to render **container** - Where to render ```html
```
## 4. JSX React JS introduced a new HTML like syntax named JSX to create elements. ```jsx const element =

Hello World

; ``` The above JSX element compiles to, ```js const elementProps = { className: "greeting"}; const childrenContent = "Hello World!"; const element = React.createElement(elementType, elementProps, childrenContent); ``` In JSX, HTML tags always need to be closed. For example, `
`, ``. ### 4.1 Babel JSX is not JavaScript. We have to convert it to JavaScript using a code compiler. Babel is one such tool. It is a JavaScript compiler that translates JSX into regular JavaScript. Import babel in head tag. ```html ``` ```html ``` - For JSX, the `type` attribute value of the HTML `script` element should be `text/babel`. - For providing class names in JSX, the attribute name should be `className`. **Differences between HTML and JSX**: | HTML | JSX | | ----- | --------- | | class | className | | for | htmlFor | ### 4.2 Embedding Variables and Expressions in JSX We can embed the variables and expressions using the flower brackets `{}`. **Embedding variables in JSX**: ```html

``` ### 4.3 Nesting JSX elements The `ReactDOM.render()` method returns only one element in render. So, we need to wrap the element in parenthesis when writing the nested elements. ```html

## 1. Component A Component is a JS function that returns a JSX element. ```jsx const Welcome = () =>

Hello, User

## 2. Real World React Apps Creating a real-world app involves lot of setup because a large number of components need to be organised. **Evan You**, the creator of **Vue.js** created a **third-party package vite** to generate a ready-made react application setup ### 2.1 NPM (Node Package Manager) [NPM](https://www.npmjs.com/) is a **package manager** with millions of packages, serving as a repository and tool for managing JavaScript project dependencies NPM Company provides a **Command line tool** which will allow you to **publish, discover, install, and develop** node programs #### 2.1.1 Creating a React app using Vite ```terminal npm create vite@8.0.2 ``` Then Give the app name, Select framework (as React) and variant (as JavaScript) ``` > root@123/.../.../# npm create vite@8.0.2 ✔ Project name: … myapp ✔ Select a framework: > React ✔ Select a variant: > JavaScript ✔ Use rolldown-vite(Experimental): > No ✔ Install with npm and start now: > Yes ``` #### 2.1.2 React Application Folder Structure Let’s quickly understand the core structure of the folders. We have 2 primary ones: - public/folder: Where we will keep assets like images, icons, videos etc - src/folder: Where we will do the majority of our work. All of our React components will placed here. The **main.jsx** is a starting point to the Application **package.json** JSON file containing the configuration for the project, including dependencies and other project details JavaScript files containing JSX syntax should be named with **.jsx** extension #### 2.1.3 Starting a React Application Install the dependencies and run **npm run dev** command from **myapp** directory ```terminal nxtwave@RJSIVIMLDB:~/components-and-props$ cd myapp nxtwave@RJSIVIMLDB:~/components-and-props/myapp$ npm run dev ``` You can view the application in the URL `http://localhost:3000` in your browser. ### 2.2 Pre-Configured tools The `create vite` comes pre-configured with: - **Live editing**: Allows **React components** to be live reloaded. - **Esbuild & Rollup**: These are tools used to stitch together a group of modules into a single file (or group of files) This process is called **Bundling** esbuild is also a **JavaScript Compiler**, compiles **JSX into Regular JavaScript**.
